description: Uncertain, possibly from Middle English poupen (“to make a gulping sound while drinking, blow on a horn, toot”). Compare Dutch poepen (“to defecate”), German Low German pupen (“to fart; break wind”). Also representing poo pronounced with the mouth snapped closed at the end.

entries.meaning: (informal, often childish) Fecal matter; feces. [from the 18th c.]
examples: The dog poop is on the grass.

entries.meaning: The sound of a steam engine's whistle, typically low-pitched.
examples: Two minutes passed - five - seven - ten. "Poop! Poop!" Everyone knew that whistle, and a mighty cheer went up as the Queen's train glided into the station.

verbs.description: poop (third-person singular simple present poops, present participle pooping, simple past and past participle pooped)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, intransitive) To make a short blast on a horn. [from late 14th c.]

examples: His horse pooped right in the middle of the parade.

description: Recorded in World War II (1941) Army slang poop sheet (“up-to-date information”), itself of uncertain origin, perhaps toilet paper (referring to etymology 1).

entries.meaning: A set of data or general information, written or spoken, usually concerning machinery or a process.
examples: Here’s the info paper with the poop on that carburetor.

verbs.description: poop (third-person singular simple present poops, present participle pooping, simple past and past participle pooped)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To tire, exhaust. Often used with out. [from early 20th c.]
examples: I'm pooped from working so hard.
He pooped out a few strides from the finish line.

description: From Middle English poupe, pope, from Old French pope, poupe, pouppe, from Italian poppa, from Vulgar Latin *puppa, from Latin puppis, all meaning “stern of a ship”.

verbs.description: poop (third-person singular simple present poops, present participle pooping, simple past and past participle pooped)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To break seawater with the poop of a vessel, especially the poop deck.
examples: We were pooped within hailing of the quay and were nearly sunk.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To embark a ship over the stern.

description: Uncertain, perhaps a shortening of nincompoop.
